channel.title: W3C Web Application Security Working Group-relevant MDN issues
channel.description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by W3C Web Application Security Working Group

item.title: [permissions] navigator.permissions.query({name:'camera'}) is not working in Safari and Firefox
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/permissions

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

navigator.permissions.query({name:'camera'})

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

when I use this navigator.permissions.query({name:'camera'}) in Safari(version 14.1.2 ) it is showing Error

Unhandled Runtime Error
TypeError: undefined is not an object (evaluating 'navigator.permissions.query')

and in FireFox (version 107.0.1) it is showing the Error
TypeError: 'camera' (value of 'name' member of PermissionDescriptor) is not a valid value for enumeration PermissionName.

What did you expect to see?

I would expect this method navigator.permissions.query({name:'camera'}) working in safari and Firefox in both mobile and desktop browsers

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/navigator/permissions
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/permissions
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/navigator/permissions/index.md
  • Last commit: 4b46382
  • Document last modified: 2022-09-09T05:17:24.000Z

item.title: [permissions-policy-1] Intent to document: Permissions-Policy
item.content:encoded:
It's time to play with this one again ;-)

There is a change to Chromium that adds wildcards to Permission-Policy origins: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5170361717489664. Unfortunately, MDN currently only documents Feature-Policy, and it wouldn't make a lot of sense to put this change inside those docs.

So I'm going to have a go at getting Permissions-Policy documented once and for all.

Things to do:

  • Change all the Feature-Policy BCD to Permissions-Policy and update the support versions. add alternative names for the browsers that did support Feature-Policy items (Fx and Saf only supported it via the <iframe allow=""> attribute.)
    • For the moment, keep Feature-Policy and Permissions-Policy so that if this gets merged and used on the site before the content updates are merged, the Feature-Policy pages don't break.
    • Include an entry for the new Chrome 108 feature — “Wildcards in origin values”
  • Update the Feature-Policy header page and its directive pages to say Permissions-Policy. @jpmedley nearly got there a while ago — see #1831, and I'll definitely use that list as a basis for my work.
    • Need to move these pages using the move command (see https://github.com/chrisdavidmills/content/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#moving-documents) so that the redirects are set up successfully.
  • Add any new directives that are missing
  • Make sure the landing pages are updated to change names and talk about the new syntax. See
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Feature_Policy
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Feature_Policy/Using_Feature_Policy
    • Again, these need to be moved with the move comment
  • Make sure the Permissions-Policy landing page is updated to talk about the relationship between it and the Permissions API; see #13003
  • Document https://chromestatus.com/feature/5170361717489664
  • Update the HTTPSidebar macro so that it links to the new Permissions-Policy pages, not Feature-Policy.

Useful pages:

  1. https://developer.chrome.com/en/docs/privacy-sandbox/permissions-policy/
  2. https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-permissions-policy/blob/main/features.md

item.title: [permissions-policy-1] "Feature-Policy": execution-while-not-rendered and execution-while-out-of-viewport documentation needs to be written
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Feature-Policy

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

execution-while-not-rendered and execution-while-out-of-viewport links are broken

Specific section or headline?

What did you expect to see?

Did you test this? If so, how?

MDN Content page report details

item.title: [permissions-policy-1] Permissions API - update to docs needed
item.content:encoded:
• Permissions API
  • Using the Permissions API

The Permission API is associated with UI features that require explicit permission from the user to access (or some equivalent proxy for permission). For example, geolocation potentially exposes very sensitive user information and hence requires explicit user permission to use. It is used by developers to determine whether permission has been granted to use the associated API.

There are a number of things to fix in the current MDN docs. The main one is that it is too easy to confuse with the Permissions API (related to user granted permissions) with the Permission Policy which provides server granted permissions to use similar features. Both APIs are similarly named and use similar/same strings to define the features.

  • We need to explicitly capture the main differences, as outlined in https://w3c.github.io/permissions/#relationship-to-permissions-policy . For example, UI vs server, the fact that if permission policy is not allowed, the permission API will always be denied.
  • Make sure that the difference is also captured in the Permission policy doc - ie. not just assume the existence of an overlap
  • Explain what the permission API permissions are - ie refer to a list.

The permissions API permissions are now defined in each spec, but registered in a powerful feature registry: https://w3c.github.io/powerful-features-registry/ we should explain that.

Other things:

  • The API is marked as experimental - that is no longer the case
  • The "Using" doc refers to quite old builds. General update would be good.

@marcoscaceres Love your work in w3c/permissions#263 . Would appreciate it if you are able to keep an eye on the MDN fixes. Not sure who will do them. Possibly me, once I finish my queue :-)

item.title: [CSP3] Issue with "Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only": deprecated report-uri recommended
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

I'm trying to sort out reporting on my Content-Security-Policy, and following the guide here shows examples using the report-uri directive. However, according to the report-uri page (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy/report-uri), this is deprecated in favour of report-to.

In addition, the report-to page recommends looking at this page to get information on how to use it, however there are no examples given, only report-uri ones.

Specific section or headline?

Any code examples

What did you expect to see?

report-to examples, instead of deprecated report-uri examples. Or actually, both, since report-to isn't supported by all browsers yet.

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/http/headers/content-security-policy-report-only
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/http/headers/content-security-policy-report-only/index.html
  • Last commit: f6f11d2
  • Document last modified: 2021-02-19T19:33:30.000Z
